sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Despite the fact that, according to the contemporary ideas, a major contribution to global warming observed in the past century comes from anthropogenic forcing, the role of natural external forcings of the climate system (and the contribution of natural climate variability as well) cannot be ruled out [1, 2]. Among the natural external forcings that are significant on decadal and centennial scales, variations in solar irradiance (including both the cyclic and the trend component) and volcanic activity can be indicated.
Major volcanic eruptions eject large amounts of sulfur compounds into the atmosphere. Most of these compounds reach the stratosphere, where they reside for one or two years [3]. The global-cooling instantaneous radiative forcing (also referred to as the radiative disturbing forcing [4]) is 3–5 W m –2
in absolute value for the largest eruptions, reaching ≈ 6 W m –2
for the most violent eruption of Mt. Tambora over the past 200 years (1815) [5, 7].
As a consequence, the volcanic eruptions lead to climate cooling within one or two years [2, 3, 8, 9]. In particular, after the eruption of Mt. Tambora, the sum-
mer of 1816 was anomalously cold (“the year without a summer”) [3]. On the other hand, in the winters that follow the eruption of a volcano in the tropics or subtropics, warming is observed over land in the extratropical latitudes of the Northern and Southern hemispheres [2, 3, 8, 9]. The latter is attributed to the response of the tropospheric circulation (a positive phase of the Arctic and Antarctic oscillations) [3, 10–12] and to the enhancement of heat advection from oceanic regions to land. The winter warming of land in the Northern Hemisphere is not manifested after high-latitude eruptions, for example, after the eruption of Mt. Katmai (1912) [13].
In addition, a decrease in the influx of solar radiation to the ocean surface causes a decrease in evaporation and the corresponding decrease in precipitation [14, 15] (see also [16, 17].
As the frequency of volcanic eruptions increases in some periods, there can be, as a result, a significant climate cooling in these periods. For example, a simultaneous decrease in the solar constant and the enhancement of volcanic activity is considered to be the primary cause of the Little Ice Age in the 17th–19th centuries [2, 3, 6, 18–20]. In turn, a decrease in volca-
—The climate model of intermediate complexity developed at the A.M. Obukhov Institute of Atmospheric Physics of the Russian Academy of Sciences (IAP RAS CM) is supplemented by a scheme which takes into account the volcanic forcing of climate. With this model, ensemble experiments have been conducted for the 1600s–1900s, in which, along with the volcanic forcing, the anthropogenic forcing due to greenhouse gases and sulfate aerosols and the natural forcing due to variations in solar irradiance were taken into account. The model realistically reproduces the annual mean response of surface air temperature and precipitation to major eruptions both globally and regionally. In particular, the decreases in the annual mean global temperature T
g in the IAP RAS CM after the largest eruptions in the latter half of the 20th century, the Mt. Agung (1963), El Chichon (1982), and Mt. Pinatubo (1991) volcanic eruptions, are 0.28, 0.27, and 0.46 K, respectively, in agreement with estimates from observational data. Moreover, in the IAP RAS CM, the volcanic eruptions result in a general precipitation decrease, especially over land in the middle and high latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere. The seasonal distribution of the response shows good agreement with observations for high-latitude eruptions and worse agreement for tropical and subtropical volcanoes. On interdecadal scales, volcanism leads to variations in T
g on the order of 0.1 K. In numerical experiments with anthropogenic and natural forcings, the model reproduces a general change in surface air temperature over the past several centuries. Taking into account the volcanic forcing, along with that due to variations in solar irradiance, the model has partly reproduced the nonmonotonic global warming for the 20th century.

nic activity and an increase in the solar constant may have been the cause of both the middle-age climatic optimum of the 9th–12th centuries [2, 3, 6, 18, 19, 21] and the warming observed in the first half of the 20th century [2, 3, 6, 18, 19, 21–23].
M.I. Budyko suggested that the response of climate to volcanic eruptions should be regarded as an essence of the method of preventing global warming related to controlled emissions of sulfur compounds into the stratosphere [24]. To date, there is growing interest in this approach [25–29]. Assessing the efficiency of such a way of preventing global warming is possible only with climate models. In this case, the uncertainty in some of the governing parameters of such a method for global warming prevention results in the necessity of conducting a large number of numerical experiments with a cumulative length of tens or hundreds of thousands of years. In the context of the latter, it is feasible to use, along with general circulation climate models, the climate models of intermediate complexity. The models of intermediate complexity assess the efficiency of the proposed method of global warming prevention both globally and regionally with reasonable computer costs [30, 31]. However, one necessary condition for using a selected climate model to assess the efficiency of the controlled climate impact related to sulfur injections into the stratosphere is the realism of the response of this model to volcanic eruptions.
This paper outlines a scheme to include volcanic forcing in the climate model of intermediate complexity developed at the A.M. Obukhov Institute of Atmospheric Physics of the Russian Academy of Sciences (IAP RAS CM) [32–36] and gives an estimate of the influence of volcanic activity on climate variations in the past several centuries. In particular, a conclusion will be made about the possible use of the IAP RAS CM for assessing the efficiency of global warming prevention related to controlled stratospheric injections of sulfur compounds.

sections.heading: 2. MODEL AND NUMERICAL EXPERIMENTS
sections.text:
In this paper, the results of numerical runs with the IAP RAS CM [32–40] were used. The model employs modules for shortwave and longwave radiation transfer, convection, and cloud and precipitation formation. In the scheme of shortwave radiation transfer, cloud cover, water vapor, ozone, and tropospheric sulfate aerosols are taken into account [33, 39]. In the scheme of longwave radiation transfer, air temperature and humidity, clouds, carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrogen monoxide are included (the latter two greenhouse gases are in the “equivalent ëé
2 ” approximation [33–36]. Large-scale atmospheric dynamics (with scales larger than those corresponding to synoptic processes) is described explicitly. The synopticscale processes are parametrized under the assumption that their ensembles are Gaussian [32, 33, 37].
The IAP RAS CM comprises schemes of the carbon [34, 35, 38–40] and methane [36] cycles. Sea ice in the model is diagnosed on the basis of surface air and sea surface temperatures. In the model version used here, surface hydrology is prescribed. The IAP RAS CM horizontal resolution is 4.5° in latitude and 6°
in longitude with eight vertical levels in the atmosphere (up to 80 km).
In this paper, results of the numerical runs with the IAP RAS CM version [36] for 1610–2000 were used. This version of the model was supplemented by a scheme for stratospheric volcanic aerosols. Their instantaneous radiative forcing at the top of the atmosphere R

The zonally averaged optical depth of volcanic aerosols in this experiment for 1610–1889 was prescribed according to the annual mean data [46], and for 1890–2000 it was prescribed according to the monthly mean data [47]. Zonal averaging of the volcanic aerosol characteristics is permissible at least for numerical experiments with climate models of intermediate complexity (and simpler models) because of the rapid transport of the product of volcanic eruptions in the atmosphere in a zonal direction. For example, a characteristic time of such a transport was three weeks for the El Chichon (1982) and Mt. Pinatubo (1991) eruptions and two weeks for the Krakatau (1883) eruption [3].

In this experiment, the annual emissions of carbon dioxide for 1860–2000 due to fossil-fuel burning and industrial activity were prescribed from the data reported in [48] and land-use emissions were prescribed according to the data of [49]. For 1610–1859, these emissions were extended back according to [50]. Anthropogenic methane emissions for 1860–2000 were prescribed from the data of [51], but 13% smaller (see discussion in [36]). Annual anthropogenic methane emissions were also extended back to 1610–2100 in accordance with [36]. The annual mean concentration of nitrogen monoxide for the 17th–20th centuries was prescribed from Greenland ice core records [52]. The variation in the total amount of tropospheric sulfate aerosols for 1860–2100 was prescribed according to the annual mean output of the atmospheric chemistry and transport model MOZART 2.0 [53]. For the earlier period, the concentration of tropospheric sulfate aerosols was set constant according to the results of [53] for 1860. Changes in the solar constant were prescribed according to [54].
In addition, the numerical experiment ALL was performed with the IAP RAS CM, in which all of the external forcings of climate listed above were taken into account.
All of the numerical experiments indicated above were performed in the form of ensembles, each of which consisted of 16 members with different initial conditions. The choice of initial conditions for various ensemble members was similar to that used in [55]. The results in the paper are presented for quantities averaged over the corresponding ensemble.
The cumulative length of the simulations was 18768 model years. Such long simulations are currently precluded for state-of-the-art general circulation models due to technical limitations. This, in particular, results in the use of computationally significantly less expen-
sive climate models of intermediate complexity [30, 31] to solve the problem formulated in this paper.

sections.heading: 3.1. Climate Response to the Strongest Volcanic Eruptions
sections.text:
The largest decrease in the magnitude of the annual mean global surface air temperature T
g in the VOL experiment is obtained for the Tambora eruption (1815) [3, 56], which amounts to 0.96 K (Fig. 1). A significant decrease in T
g of 0.58 K is also found for the Grimsvotn (Laki) eruption (1783) [3, 56] and 0.59 K for an unknown volcano (1809) [56]. In the 19th century, a strong global response of 0.42 K in the model is also obtained for the Cosiguina eruption (1835) [3] and 0.24 K for Krakatau (1883) [3, 56]. In the 20th century, the largest decrease in T
g of 0.46 K in the IAP RAS CM is obtained for the eruption of Mt. Pinatubo (1991) [3, 56]. This value generally agrees with an estimate of 0.5 ± 0.1
K obtained after the removal of the El Nino effect from observational data [57, 58]. A considerable decrease in global temperature in the IAP RAS CM is also obtained for the eruptions of Santa Maria (1902), Katmai (1912), Agung (1963), and El Chichon (1982) [3, 56], which is equal to 0.37, 0.17, 0.28, and 0.27 K, respectively. The model response to the latter two eruptions agrees with empirical estimates of 0.2 ± 0.1 and 0.4 ± 0.1 K, respec-

tively [57]. For the Mt. Pinatubo eruption, the response of the IAP RAS CM is close to that obtained with general circulation models GFDL R30 [14], GFDL CM2 [23], and CCSM3 [22], with climate models of intermediate complexity CLIMBER-2 and MoBidiC [18, 19], and with energy balance model [6]. On the other hand, the IAP RAS CM response to the Tambora eruption is larger than that obtained in the CLIMBER-2 and MoBidiC climate models of intermediate complexity (in both cases, ≈ 0.7
K [18, 19]) and in energy balance model [6] (for which the response to this eruption is ≈ 0.6
K). The latter appears to be related to the difference in reconstructions of volcanism characteristics used in [6, 18, 19], on the one hand, and in this paper, on the other, and also to a large uncertainty in such reconstructions up to the mid-20th century (reaching 50% in some cases [7]).
The model response to the Mt. Pinatubo eruption (as an example of a strong eruption of a tropical volcano) in summer is characterized by a surface cooling of 0.5–1 K over most of the Northern Hemisphere extratropical land and the South Ocean (Fig. 2a). This agrees qualitatively with an observational estimate for March–October [59]. The IAP RAS CM winter response (Fig. 2b) is also characterized by a strong cooling, maximal over Northern Hemisphere extratropical land (>1 K). It is significantly different from the observations of [2, 3]. It should be noted that winter warming over extratropical land areas is not reproduced by a number of other present-day climate models [60].
The response of precipitation to the Mt. Pinatubo eruption in the IAP RAS CM (Fig.3) is characterized by the formation of a strong dry anomaly in the extratropical zone. This agrees qualitatively with results of an analysis of precipitation data [3, 15] and with the results of simulations with other climate models (e.g., [14, 16, 17]).
The model response to the Katmai eruption (as an example of a strong high-latitude eruption) is also characterized by significant cold anomalies at the surface in the extratropical zone of the Northern Hemisphere. Over extratropical land regions of this hemisphere, the cooling in the winter of 1913 is 1–2 K, with an average for 1913 reaching 0.5–1 K. These
results are generally consistent with the corresponding results of the numerical experiments with the GISS-E general circulation model [13].

sections.heading: 3.2. Influence of Volcanic Activity on Climate Changes in the 18th–20th Centuries
sections.text:
The intensity of volcanic activity in the 20th century varied nonmonotonically, with an enhancement in the first decade and early in the second decade, a subsequent decrease up to the early 1960s, and an enhancement in the next three decades. For this reason, the estimated linear trends of the 20th-century surface air temperature in the VOL ensemble experiment are statistically insignificant in global averages (table) as well as in separate seasons.
In the VOL experiment, however, a general cooling in 1963–1995 (with a higher intensity of volcanic activity) relative to 1915–1962 can be noted (Fig. 4a). On average each year, the decrease in surface air temperature í
a , s is 0.1–0.2 K over Northern Hemisphere land and over Antarctica regions. The cooling in winter is somewhat stronger than in summer.
The period of 1915–1962 also turns out to be warmer than the previous 1883–1914 period of high volcanism intensity (Fig. 4b). The magnitude of global temperature change between these periods is 0.1–0.2 K over Northern Hemisphere land.
An even larger change in í
a , s is revealed between the 1782–1837 period with high volcanic activity and the 1838–1882 period with low volcanic activity (Fig. 4c). A noticeable response of temperature is observed not only over middle- and high-latitude land, but also in the tropics. At low latitudes, warming occurs over both land and oceans.
In the global mean, the temperature change between the two periods with high and low volcanism is –0.08 K from 1915–1962 to 1963–1995 and 0.07 K for from 1883–1914 to 1915–1962. The first two values are much smaller than the 0.74 ± 0.18
K change in the 20th-century global surface air temperature [2]. They are also smaller than typical values of global warming from the 1910s to the 1930s (0.35 K [2]) and from the 1970s to the present (0.55 K [2]). In this connection, volcanic activity should not be regarded as one of the main causes of climate variations in the 20th century on the whole. However, the model response between 1883–1914 and 1915–1962 is already comparable in the order of magnitude to the global warming of the 1910s–1930s. As a consequence, it may be assumed that the role of volcanic activity in this warming is not negligible. This generally agrees with the conclusions drawn in [2, 3, 6, 18, 19, 21–23].

sections.heading: 3.3. Model Temperature Variation in the 18th–20th Centuries in Numerical Experiments with Natural and Anthropogenic Forcings
sections.text:
In the 20th century, the ALL numerical experiment reveals upward trends of T
a , s that are statistically significant over most of the Northern Hemisphere and over tropics and subtropics of the Southern Hemisphere (Fig. 5a). In regions where the model produces a statistically significant trend, its magnitude over tropical and subtropical oceans is 0.2–0.5 K/century. Over midlatitude and polar oceans and over land, the trend of surface air temperature rise is 0.2–1 K/century, with maxima in Siberia, central Asia, northern North America, and Greenland. Such a spatial structure of the trends of T
a , s and their magnitude agree with empirical estimates for the 20th century [2].
In the GHGSASOL experiment, the magnitude of the trend of T
a , s varies slightly relative to that in the ALL experiment, but the region where the trend is statistically significant decreases sharply, embracing only the extratropical land of the Northern Hemi-
sphere and a small area in the northern part of the Pacific. This appears to be related to the influence of volcanic forcing on the intensity of variability in the IAP RAS CM.
For the longer period of 1750–2000 (Fig. 5b), the model trends of surface air temperature are statistically significant almost worldwide except in the subtropical region off the west coast of North America and small oceanic regions near Antarctica. The magnitude of the trend coefficient is <0.1 K/century in the southeast of Europe and in the equatorial region and 0.1–0.2 K/century in many other regions worldwide. As in the 20th century, maxima in this period are observed in Siberia, central Asia, Alaska, and Greenland, but with absolute values smaller than those found for the 20th century.
In the global mean, the increase in surface air temperature by the mid-19th century relative to the early 17th century is about 0.6 K for both ALL and GHGSASOL experiments (Fig. 6). A major contribution to this warming in the IAP RAS CM comes from a general growth of the solar constant in this period [50, 63, 64]. Additional (with respect to GHGSASOL) consideration for volcanic forcing in the ALL experiment results in brief (1–3 years long) cool spells after large eruptions, with a negligible difference in T
g between these two experiments in periods with low volcanic activity. In the period of instrumental data (the second half of the 19th century and the 20th century), the global warming in the model accelerates and T
g

ally increases by ≈0.8 K, including ≈0.75 K in the 20th century (Fig. 6). The latter value agrees well with an empirical estimate of 0.74 ± 0.18 K[2]. Including volcanic forcing, along with the influence of variations in solar irradiance, in the IAP RAS CM made it possible to partly reproduce the nonmonotonic global warming in the 20th century, with a global temperature increase in the 1910s–1930s and 1970s–1980s and a decrease in the 1940s–1960s. However, the difference of interdecadal temperature variations in the 20th century between the IAP RAS CM and observations remains large and may be related to the role of natural climate variability in such variations [65–67] and to the omission of other impacts on climate (for example, ozone changes in the atmosphere).
It should be noted that, relative to other reconstructions of the Sun’s irradiance for the past several centuries, the reconstruction under use [54] is characterized by the lowest interdecadal and centennial variations in the solar constant (e.g., [2]). The earlier reconstructions of the Sun’s irradiance for the past several centuries were characterized by an excessive centennial and interdecadal variability, correspondingly overestimating the climate response [2, 68, 69].
The linear trend of íg in the IAP RAS CM hardly differs between the numerical experiments GHGSASOL and ALL (table), amounting to ≈0.6 K/century for the 20th century and ≈0.3 K/century for 1750–2000. The
lower value of the linear trend of global temperature in the 20th century relative to the total temperature change suggests a further acceleration of warming in the second half of the 20th century. Such an accelerated growth of surface air temperature in the 20th century relative to the previous several centuries, pronounced both globally and regionally in the IAP RAS CM, is consistent with the inferences drawn in [2, 40].
Climate warming in the IAP RS CM is accompanied by a decrease in the amplitude of the annual harmonic of Ta,s (Fig. 7), which indicates that warming predominates in winter as compared to summer. This is in qualitative agreement with results of observational analysis and reanalysis data [1, 2, 70–73]. The negative correlation between changes in the annual mean Ta,s and its annual harmonic in the IAP RAS CM is manifested with both anthropogenic variations alone [39, 72, 73] and volcanic forcing (see above). However, the coefficient of regression of the amplitude of the annual harmonic of Ta,s on the 20th-century annual mean surface air temperature is generally lower than that from reanalysis data [73].

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
The climate model of intermediate complexity developed at the A.M. Obukhov Institute of Atmospheric Physics of the Russian Academy of Sciences

(IAP RAS CM) has been supplemented by a module for the volcanic forcing of climate. Ensemble numerical experiments have been performed with the model for the 17th–20th centuries in which, along with the volcanic forcing, the anthropogenic forcing due to greenhouse gases and sulfate aerosols and the natural forcing due to variations in solar irradiance were included. The results are presented for the ensembleaverage quantities. The model realistically reproduces the annual mean response of surface air temperature Ta,s and precipitation to major eruptions on both global and

regional scales. In particular, the decreases in the annual mean global temperature Tg in the IAP RAS CM after the largest eruptions of the second half of the 20th centuries, Mt. Agung (1963), El Chichon (1982), and Mt. Pinatubo, are 0.28, 0.27, and 0.46 K, respectively, in agreement with estimates from observational data. The response of Ta,s to individual eruptions in the IAP RAS CM reaches a maximum over Northern Hemisphere land areas. The winter cooling in the model is much larger than the summer one. For highlatitude eruptions, the latter result agrees with the observations and results of numerical experiments with other current climate models. For eruptions of tropical and subtropical volcanoes, in contrast, such a seasonal distribution of the response disagrees with observations. It should be noted, however, that such a discrepancy is common to some other state-of-the-art climate models [60].
In the IAP RAS CM, volcanic eruptions lead to a general precipitation decrease, which is also most considerable over land in the middle and high latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere. This generally agrees with estimates from observational data. On decadal scales, volcanic activity results in Tg variations on the order of 0.1 K.
In the numerical experiments with natural and anthropogenic forcing, the model reproduced a general change in surface temperature over the past several centuries. The experiments with the volcanic forcing of climate, along with the forcing due to variations in solar irradiance, have in part reproduced the warming at the beginning and end of the 20th century and the cooling in the middle of the century.
As was indicated in the Introduction, volcanic eruptions can be used to assess the efficiency of the global warming prevention method related to controlled emissions of sulfur compounds into the stratosphere [24–29]. The results obtained in the paper allow the use of the IAP RAS CM for assessing the efficiency of this approach, at least for the annual mean climate characteristics [74]. Such an estimate with the IAP RAS CM will be presented in a separate paper.

abstractText: The climate model of intermediate complexity developed at the A.M. Obukhov Institute of Atmospheric Physics of the Russian Academy of Sciences (IAP RAS CM) is supplemented by a scheme which takes into account the volcanic forcing of climate. With this model, ensemble experiments have been conducted for the 1600s–1900s, in which, along with the volcanic forcing, the anthropogenic forcing due to greenhouse gases and sulfate aerosols and the natural forcing due to variations in solar irradiance were taken into account. The model realistically reproduces the annual mean response of surface air temperature and precipitation to major eruptions both globally and regionally. In particular, the decreases in the annual mean global temperature T g in the IAP RAS CM after the largest eruptions in the latter half of the 20th century, the Mt. Agung (1963), El Chichon (1982), and Mt. Pinatubo (1991) volcanic eruptions, are 0.28, 0.27, and 0.46 K, respectively, in agreement with estimates from observational data. Moreover, in the IAP RAS CM, the volcanic eruptions result in a general precipitation decrease, especially over land in the middle and high latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere. The seasonal distribution of the response shows good agreement with observations for high-latitude eruptions and worse agreement for tropical and subtropical volcanoes. On interdecadal scales, volcanism leads to variations in T g on the order of 0.1 K. In numerical experiments with anthropogenic and natural forcings, the model reproduces a general change in surface air temperature over the past several centuries. Taking into account the volcanic forcing, along with that due to variations in solar irradiance, the model has partly reproduced the nonmonotonic global warming for the 20th century. title: Influence of Volcanic Activity on Climate Change in the Past Several Centuries: Assessments with a Climate Model of Intermediate Complexity
